'Yitzhak Rabin' (; ; 1 March 1922 â 4 November 1995) was an Israeli politician,
statesman and general. He was the fifth Prime Minister of Israel, serving two
terms in office, 1974â77 and 1992 until his assassination in 1995.

In 1994, Rabin won the Nobel Peace Prize together with Shimon Peres and Yasser
Arafat. He was assassinated by right-wing Israeli radical Yigal Amir, who was
opposed to Rabin's signing of the Oslo Accords. Rabin was the first native-born
prime minister of Israel, the only prime minister to be assassinated and the
second to die in office after Levi Eshkol.

He was voted number one in a 2005 Ynet poll of greatest Israelis.
